results.justification: The document explicitly states the research methodology, introducing "Transition Network Analysis (TNA)" as a novel method.
Section 3.1, 'Implementation of the method', provides a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, including data coding, Markov model estimation, and clustering.
The document does not state that the raw or processed datasets are publicly available.
While no data is shared, there is no explicit justification for why the data cannot be shared.
Table 1 serves as a data dictionary, explaining the coding scheme for chat discussions, including variables and descriptions.
The document describes the data collection methods: "students had to collaborate together online using chats...The students' online chat discussions were collected and coded..."
The document states: "We also present an R package [19] as well as a set of step-by-step tutorials to aid researchers in implementing TNA [32]."
Code is shared, so justification for not sharing is not relevant.
The document mentions the use of R packages 'tna' and 'seqHMM' for data preparation and analysis, implying code for preprocessing exists.
Statistical tests (e.g., BIC for cluster selection), models (Markov models, Stochastic Process Mining), and assumptions (first-order dependency) are described.
Effect sizes (e.g., Cohen's kappa = 0.61), and statistical values (e.g., t-values, p-values) are reported.
The analysis is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
The study is not primarily qualitative, so data coding and analysis details are not extensively shared in a qualitative manner.
Results are presented with descriptions of TNA plots, centrality measures, patterns (dyads, cliques, communities, clusters), and covariate analysis.
Section 4.6, 'Limitations', discusses potential biases and limitations of the method, such as sample size requirements and assumptions of Markov models.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
